message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that both pupils respond when light is shone into the right eye but not the left suggests an afferent defect. The optic nerve mediates afferent pupillary reflex, so the lesion is most likely located in the optic nerve. Pretectal nuclei are also involved in pupillary reflex but damage to them would affect both eyes. Superior cervical ganglion and ciliary ganglion are not involved in pupillary reflex.

The pretectal nuclei are responsible for the pupillary light reflex, but since the right pupil still reacts, it is less likely to be the cause. The superior cervical ganglion and ciliary ganglion are not involved in the pupillary light reflex.
